G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 because the amount in controversy does not exceed $50,000 and because the events giving rise to this cause of action occurred within the jurisdictional district of this Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Worcester District Court under G.L. c. 223, § 2 because the Defendant resides and/or does business in Worcester County and the tortious conduct giving rise to the injury occurred there.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 15.proposition: Defendant, as the owner and landlord of the Property, owed a duty under Massachusetts law, including G.L. c. 186, § 15, and under common law, to exercise reasonable care in maintaining the Property, including the adjacent sidewalk, in a reasonably safe condition for lawful visitors.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty of reasonable care to keep the sidewalk and approaches to the Property in a safe condition for lawful visitors.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: The excerpt is from a concurring opinion discussing general occupier’s liability categories (invitee, licensee, trespasser) and criticizing reliance on those labels. It does not mention sidewalks, approaches to property, or specifically articulate a duty to keep such areas safe for lawful visitors. While the full Mounsey decision does reform premises liability duties broadly, this particular cited text does not clearly establish the specific sidewalk/approach duty stated in the proposition.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that ‘trespassers’ stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential. This tends to perpetuate, although on a smaller scale, the kind of tradition-bound and mistaken analysis that I had supposed the court was aiming to correct."

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s duty included, but was not limited to, the duty to remove snow and ice hazards or otherwise make the area reasonably safe.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly holds that property owners owe to lawful visitors a general duty of reasonable care with respect to hazards arising from snow and ice, placing such hazards on the same footing as all other dangers on the premises. In describing that duty, the court indicates that owners must make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors and to keep walkways, stairs, and parking lots reasonably safe, which includes reasonable snow and ice removal or other measures to make the area safe. This aligns with the proposition that the defendant’s duty includes, but is not limited to, removing snow and ice hazards or otherwise making the area reasonably safe.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances….’ … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

Sullivan v. Brookline, 435 Mass. 353 (20.proposition: Defendant’s duty included, but was not limited to, the duty to remove snow and ice hazards or otherwise make the area reasonably safe.
Sullivan v. Brookline, 435 Mass. 353 (20.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns reinstatement of a disabled police officer and the interaction between retirement and civil service statutes; it does not address premises liability, landowner duties, or any obligation to remove snow and ice or make an area reasonably safe. There is no discussion of tort duties to entrants on land or maintenance of physical premises. Therefore, this case does not provide authority for the stated proposition about a defendant’s duty regarding snow and ice hazards.

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.proposition: Defendant’s acts and omissions were unreasonable and constituted negligence under Massachusetts law, including the principles articulated in Papadopoulos, Mounsey, and Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (2013).
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses Massachusetts negligence principles for landowners, explicitly reaffirming Mounsey and Papadopoulos and applying them to the facts of Dos Santos. The SJC holds that a landowner owes a duty of reasonable care, including a duty to remedy even open and obvious dangers, where the landowner created and maintained a dangerous condition knowing lawful entrants would nonetheless encounter it. That framework directly supports using Dos Santos, together with Papadopoulos and Mounsey, for the proposition that defendant’s unreasonable acts and omissions can constitute negligence under Massachusetts law.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises. … This duty includes an obligation to maintain the ‘property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ Mounsey v. Ellard… A landowner, though, ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] “can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm…”’ Papadopoulos v. Target Corp…. On these facts, a jury were entitled to conclude that the defendants owed a duty of care — specifically a duty to remedy — despite the open and obvious nature of the danger.”}

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).proposition: Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006) – Discussing duty, breach, and proximate cause in negligence cases.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses the elements of negligence, explicitly stating that a plaintiff must prove duty, breach, damages, and causal relation, and then analyzes duty as a question of law while identifying breach and proximate cause as issues for the jury. Although the holding centers on duty, the court clearly situates that discussion within the broader negligence framework that includes breach and causation. Thus, the case is appropriately cited as discussing duty, breach, and proximate cause in negligence cases.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. … We generally consider the latter three questions — whether a defendant exercised reasonable care, the extent of the damage caused, and whether the defendant’s breach and the damage were causally related — to be the special province of the jury.”

Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.raw_text: Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mass. 37 (2009)
Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.proposition: Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mass. 37 (2009) – Setting forth the four elements of negligence under Massachusetts law.
Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.support_reasoning: The court explicitly states the elements a plaintiff must prove to prevail on a negligence claim under Massachusetts law: duty, breach, damage, and causal relation between the breach and the damage. It cites prior Massachusetts authority for this formulation. This directly aligns with the proposition that Leavitt is cited for setting forth the four elements of negligence in Massachusetts.
Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.relevant_excerpt: "To prevail on his negligence claims, Leavitt must prove that the hospital owed him a duty of reasonable care, that the hospital committed a breach of that duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of duty and the damage. See Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006), citing J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 11.1 (3d ed. 2005); Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355, 358 (1990)."

O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201 (.proposition: O’Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201 (2000) – Duty to protect against open and obvious dangers is fact‑dependent.
O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201 (.support_reasoning: The case strongly reaffirms the traditional open-and-obvious danger rule as a duty-negating doctrine and holds, as a matter of law on summary judgment, that the pool-owner owed no duty because the danger was open and obvious. The court expressly treats whether a danger is open and obvious as a legal duty question that can be resolved by the judge when only one conclusion can be drawn from the facts, rather than as a generally fact-dependent, jury issue. Thus it undercuts rather than supports the proposition that the duty to protect against open and obvious dangers is fact‑dependent.
O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201 (.relevant_excerpt: “Whether a defendant has a duty of care to the plaintiff in the circumstances is a question of law for the court… Landowners are relieved of the duty to warn of open and obvious dangers on their premises… Because … the open and obvious danger rule … operates to negate the existence of a duty of care (emphasis added). … [W]e are persuaded that the facts of this case would necessitate summary judgment in favor of the defendants…. [T]he defendants had no duty to warn the plaintiff of this danger as a matter of law.”

Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.raw_text: Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101 (1978)
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.proposition: Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101 (1978) – Landowner liability for failure to warn or remedy hazardous conditions.
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.support_reasoning: The case holds that the landowning terminal operator (Massachusetts Port Authority) could be found negligent for failing to secure a dangerous instrumentality (the forklift) on its premises, where it was foreseeable that unauthorized and intoxicated third parties could misuse it and injure lawful visitors. While framed in terms of negligent failure to secure an instrumentality rather than an explicit ‘duty to warn,’ it squarely addresses landowner liability for hazardous conditions on the property and the failure to remedy or control those hazards. Thus it supports the general proposition of landowner liability for failure to address hazardous conditions.
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.relevant_excerpt: “It was thus reasonably foreseeable that the forklift, when left unsecured with the keys in the ignition on premises which were solely under the authority’s control, would be operated by unauthorized persons, including inebriated seamen who the authority knew had unfettered access to the cargo area. It was also reasonably foreseeable, because of the complexity of the operation of such a dangerous machine, that unauthorized operation would likely cause harm to persons known to pass through the area, such as those visiting the ships…. Consequently, a jury could have found that the plaintiff’s injury was caused by a negligent act for which the authority was responsible.”

Mass. Gen. Laws c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Mass. Gen. Laws c. 231, § 85 – Comparative negligence standard in tort actions.

G.L. c. 261, \u00a7\u00a7 1 and 13.proposition: C. Award costs of this action pursuant to G.L. c. 261, §§ 1 and 13;
